b.i: We inspire, educate, and empower students to envision and achieve a positive future for themselves and their community.

span.data-link-text: Argo See Something Say Something Hotline

a.span: Argo See Something Say Something Hotline

div.div: COVID-19

p.strong: Need some extra information on COVID-19 and Social Distancing? Please read these articles:

strong.a: How to Help Your High School Senior Through COVID-19 Pandemic
NAMI: COVID-19 Resource and Information Guide

div.div: Dear Argo Families, Staff, and Students,

This afternoon Governor Pritzker extended the school closure mandate for the remainder of the school year because of COVID-19. This news is sad for our students, our staff and the entire school community. I would have never imagined this is how we would end the 2019-2020 school year and I am disappointed. I miss seeing our students in classrooms, hallways, and on our athletic fields every day. There are many questions you will have and, honestly, I have many questions too. As an administration we have many details to figure out in the coming days so we can communicate with you all.

Over the coming weeks, it is critical that students connect with our teachers and staff to support them through this difficult time. Their disappointment and grief is very real and it is so important for them to have an outlet for those feelings. Please reach out to our counselors and social workers for social-emotional supports. We are here to support our students and their families during these difficult times. Our teachers, counselors, and social workers are using Microsoft Teams, Zoom or other digital platforms to engage students who all need face-to-face interactions. I thank our amazing staff for their innovation in these unprecedented times who are doing all they can to provide those digital face-to-face opportunities.

Argo students will continue with E-Learning through the end the school year, which is Friday, May 22, 2020. Mondays will continue to be Mental Health Mondays for students to participate in activities created by our staff, while teachers work with their course teams. It is critical that students continue with their learning routines and connections with their teachers.

Seniors, we fully acknowledge how disappointing this is. We admire your courage, resilience, and support for one another as the Class of 2020. We are working with SeatGeek Stadium and The Odyssey Club to reschedule graduation and prom for late July. We know these end-of-high-school events are very important to you and we would like you to be able to celebrate with one another.

Argo High School and Districts 104, 108 and 109 will continue serving Grab and Go Meals Monday-Friday through May 22, 2020. The Argo main entrance is the Grab and Go location at Argo from 8:30am-10:30am for children 18 and under.

There are many, many details to work out regarding how we will close out this school year. This coming week the administration will work to create a plan and communicate with you all about how we will proceed.

It is at times like this that we must pull together to support one another. Thank you again for your patience as we navigate these difficult challenges. If you have questions or need assistance over the coming weeks, please email elearning@argohs.net.
Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield, Superintendent
Dear Argo Families and Students,

Please read this entire email (it’s long but includes very important information). This afternoon Governor Pritzker announced the Illinois Stay at Home and Remote Learning orders will continue through April 30, 2020. Hopefully we will be able to return to school on May 1, however only time will tell.

We will continue with our E-Learning/Remote Learning plan as previously communicated. Friday, April 10th is a scheduled non-attendance day, so E-Learning will not be expected that day. On Mondays all students are not required to do E-Learning and are encouraged to participate in Mental Health Monday activities while teachers plan for E-Learning with their teams.

ul.li: April 1-3
April 7-9
April 14-17
April 21-24
April 28-30

div.b: Notice for Use of Video Conferencing /E-Platforms

div.div: The District is providing this notice regarding the use of audio/video learning that the District is currently offering for learning at home. The District may use live and recorded audio/video conferences with teachers and other educational personnel in order to deliver educational services. Your student will be able to participate in any such conferences offered by the District for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.

These services will be provided by using Zoom for Education, Microsoft Teams, Canvas, and Google Meet. Both programs have been designed for educational use and include security features to prevent unauthorized users from accessing student data and information. Although the instructional content delivered via this platform will be largely consistent with what is provided in the school setting, we understand the context is different given both the method of delivery of and having the service delivered in the home setting. If for any reason you are not comfortable with instruction/related service through video conferencing, please contact Dr. Chris Covino at ccovino@argohs.net to discuss alternative means to provide this instruction/related service.

Also, as a reminder during our remote learning days, school policy regarding sharing of student information remains in place. When students are present in the school buildings and receiving classroom instruction, audio and video recordings and photography by parents or other visitors to the school are not allowed without the advance permission of the teacher and the written consent of the parents/guardians of the students who will be photographed. This same standard applies to our remote learning instruction. Students and parents/guardians should refrain from making audio and/or video recordings of remote learning instruction, or taking photographs of students participating in such instruction, without express permission of the teacher delivering the instruction or a school administrator. If you receive such recordings or photographs from a source other than Argo High School District 217, delete them and do not post or forward.

Grab & Go meals continue to be available from our Main Entrance from 8:30am-10:30am. We are able to provide one meal (breakfast and lunch) per child 18 & under per day. Grab & Go meals will not be available on Friday, April 10, 2020. Please know that no food is going to waste and families who are in need are grateful for the food assistance. Thank you to our fantastic Arbor Food Service staff who are now preparing meals for Argo and Districts 104, 108 and 109. They have truly demonstrated their dedication and commitment to our school community.

ul.li: Summit and Bedford Park: St.Blase Church in Summit
Bridgeview, Justice, Willow Springs: Justice Food Pantry
Greater Chicago Food Depository: https://www.chicagosfoodbank.org/find-food/
Pillars
COVID Coping Helpline: 708-995-3898
Behavioral Health crisis (e.g., suicidal thoughts, aggression toward others, sudden trauma, etc.), Call
708-PILLARS (708-745-5277), press 1 for English/2 for Spanish, then 3 for Mental Health
Domestic violence hotline: 708-485-5254
Sexual assault hotline: 708-482-9600

div.div: Yale webinars: Offers free webinars to help cope using emotional intelligence to combat COVID-19 anxiety. It is very easy to register for their webinars.

div.b: Anxiety and Depression Association of America

div.div: Coronavirus Anxiety – Helpful Expert Tips and Resources
Supporting Families During COVID-19

For other resources and information related to COVID-19, please see our website at https://www.argohs.net/covid-19. We will continue to contact you with information and resources. If you need assistance with academic or social-emotional supports, please contact us at elearning@argohs.net or call at 708-467-5526.If you have technical problems email helpdesk@argohs.net or call 708-467-5526.
Thank you again for your patience and understanding during this difficult time. We will continue to be in communication with you as new information becomes available.
Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield, Superintendent
Dear Argonaut Students and Families,

We hope you, your family and loved ones are safe and healthy – that is the most important thing right now. Your teachers and our entire staff miss the day to day interactions with all of you. We are working very hard to find alternative ways to connect with you during this very unusual time in your (and our) educational lives. Please continue to check our website, your email and especially our social media to see all the different ways that you can stay connected to Argo. Please take one of our Virtual Spirit Week Challenges and post your pictures (appropriately!)
As we launch into the second week of eLearning we want to make you aware of a few pieces of information given to us by the Illinois Department of Education. In the end eLearning is about two things:

1. Staying engaged with learning no matter where you are. Each day that we are eLearning you should continue to log into Canvas for assignments at 9:00am. You should also use the link at the top of the page to record your attendance. Most of you did a terrific job with this during the first week. Keep up the good work!

2. Making the most of this opportunity to focus on the classes where you are struggling. We know that some of you are currently carrying failing grade in a class. We have asked all teachers to take late work and to offer make up assessments for all of you in every class. We will be reaching out specifically and personally to all of you who have Fs to make sure that you know that we are still here to support you. We want to make sure that you know that you can still succeed!

All of your teachers will continue to create assignments, and they expect you to complete them. Teachers will be grading your work, providing you feedback, and entering your scores in the grade book. This is a time for all students to get those grades up – especially those of you who have fallen a little behind.

One other thing we want you to know. Next week, we are starting Mental Wellness Mondays. On these days, your teachers will NOT be putting out NEW assignments for you, but instead you will see posted on Canvas mental, emotional and physical ways for you to take care of yourself – like taking a walk or calling a grandparent. These simple wellness breaks are so important. Monday can also be a day that you use to catch up on any missing or late assignments.

ul.li: If you have questions about a class or work that needs to be done, please contact your teacher.
If you have questions about eLearning write us at elearning@argohs.net or call at 708-467-5526.
If you have technical problems email helpdesk@argohs.net or call 708-467-5526.

div.b: Please remember that school is ALWAYS open – just not in the same way it was a few weeks ago. We are here to help and support you, always!

div.div: Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield, Superintendent
Dear Argo Families,

On Monday, March 30, 2020 Argo students will have an additional day of spring vacation. They will not be required to do E-Learning. Teachers will spend the day working with their departments and teams to develop E-Learning/Remote Learning materials and assignments.

On Tuesday, March 31, through Tuesday, April 7, 2020 all Argo students will be required to complete the digital attendance form at 9:00am and then log into Canvas to see what assignments have been posted for them to complete. It is very important that we have your parent/guardian support in encouraging your student to continue learning during this time, as mandated by the State of Illinois. At this time, we are still waiting from information from the Governor regarding any extension to the school closure mandate.
More information will be emailed on Monday, March 30 about student grades during this mandatory school closure time.
If you have any questions, please email elearning@argohs.net.
Respectfully,
Dear Argo Families and Students,

This afternoon the Governor extended the school closure mandate through April 7, 2020. We plan to return for classes at Argo on Wednesday, April 8, 2020. Argo students will continue with E-Learning on Monday, March 30 through Tuesday, April 7, 2020. As we reflect on this past week, I hope students have established learning routines and connections with their teachers. It will be important to re-establish those learning routines starting on March 30th.

Argo High School and Districts 104, 108 and 109 will continue serving Grab and Go Meals Monday-Friday on March 20 through Tuesday, April 7. Please stop by the Argo main entrance from 8:30am-10:30am if you need Grab and Go Meal assistance.
Thank you again for your support and understanding as we navigate these difficult challenges. If you have questions or need assistance over the coming weeks, please email elearning@argohs.net.
Sincerely,
Dear Argo Families and Students,

I understand there may be some confusion regarding grading during the mandatory closure period. The current school closure days are considered Act of God Days starting today, March 17, 2020. These days will not need to be made up at the end of the school year. But this does not mean that school stops. Our E-Learning plan provides students an opportunity for continuous learning.
On Friday afternoon, Superintendents were directed by the Governor to do whatever we can to provide learning opportunities for our students during these challenging circumstances.

ul.li: “All days that a school is closed pursuant to the Governor’s Executive Order 2020-05 will be counted Act of God Days. Emergency Days will not be used. At this time, these Act of God Days do not need to be made up at the end of the school year. School districts are strongly encouraged to provide instruction to students during these Act of God Days through whatever means possible.”

div.div: In an effort to encourage continuous learning during our mandatory closure, and because we know that effective feedback is important, it is our District’s decision to continue with the E-Learning plan communicated last Friday. E-Learning will occur March 17-20 and March 30, 2020. Students can expect the following from their teachers on E-Learning days.

ul.li: Continue to assign daily work through Canvas.
Collect the work and provide feedback (score, grade, etc.).

Put assignments and scores into PowerSchool to provide meaningful feedback for students and parents about assignment completion and progress towards learning goals. All assignments will be marked as ‘does not count toward final grade’ in PowerSchool IF assigned during the Act of God days - March 17-20 and March 30.
All work assigned before March 17th may be assessed and recorded in PowerSchool as normal (March 16th is an approved E-Learning day so work in PowerSchool can count).
A teacher may set a due date for assignments for a reasonable time after schools are allowed to resume normal daily attendance.

div.div: Our message today to students is very clear: We will continue learning as a school community through our E-Learning Plan. Students are expected to complete the daily attendance form and log into Canvas to complete work by 2:00pm each day or by the teacher assigned deadline.

The short answer is yes, in fact it worked Monday for about 1750 students and many more after we provided a little help. One of the changes we are making for Tuesday, March 17th is to send a reminder with the direct link to the attendance login page. This link as well as the link at the top of the Canvas Page seemed to work every time. Students were able to quickly realize that when they used their phones to log in, the attendance link worked every time as well.

Students who failed to log in received an email reminding them of their responsibility. Starting today our deans will be calling those students who have missed two days. This practice will continue for the remainder of the week.

div.b: Who do students contact if they need help?

div.div: All information related to our E-Learning plan can be found at https://www.argohs.net/e-learning.
If a student has a question about an assignment, they should contact their teacher before 2:00 on the day it was assigned.
If a student has a technical (computer) problem, they should email helpdesk@argohs.net or call 708-467-5526.
If a student has a question about attendance or eLearning generally, they should contact elearning@argohs.net or call 708-467-5526.

div.b: What do families do if they rely of District 217 for meals during school days?

div.div: We will continue to provide Grab & Go Meals at our Main Entrance for children 18 and under from Monday-Friday, until March 30th. Our feeder schools are doing the same, so please reference their websites for details about Grab & Go Meals distribution locations.

I want to thank our amazing teachers and staff or their dedication to our students and the hours of hard work they are putting in to provide E-Learning opportunities for our students to keep up with their learning.

A huge shout out goes to our custodial and maintenance crews who are working tirelessly to very deeply clean our building. I am so proud to work alongside such amazing professionals who are truly dedicated to the Argo High School community.
Sincerely,
Dear Argo Parents and Guardians,

Thank you again for your continued support and patience during these difficult challenges. The Governor gave an executive order on Friday afternoon that all schools are to be closed through Monday, March 30, 2020. Therefore, we will hope to open our doors on Tuesday, March 31, 2020. I will be in communication with you all if any details change.

Argo Community High School will be offering Grab and Go Breakfast and Lunch Meals to all of our students at the Argo Main Entrance from 8:30-10:30a.m., Monday through Friday between March 16-30, 2020.

Our E-Learning Plan will start on Monday, March 16. Students are required to complete the online attendance form by 9:00am every day, March 16-20 and March 30. Then they will log into Canvas to see what assignments they need to complete by 2:00pm. All information regarding the E-Learning Plan can be found at https://www.argohs.net/e-learning. If you have any questions over coming weeks about E-Learning, please email elearning@argohs.net.

During this time, it will be very common for your children to want to schedule social events with friends. They will get restless and will want to connect socially. It is completely understandable, as we will all be feeling that way possibly. We highly recommend families practice social distancing over the coming weeks. This is a drastic, but we believe critical, measure. For it to be effective and not anxiety producing, we ask that you take the following actions based on recommendations by the CDC and the Cook County Health Department:

ul.li: Avoid gathering in public places - especially in close proximity to others.
Avoid close contact with those who are sick.
Try to keep 6-10 feet between yourself and others - give yourself space.
Be at home as much as possible.
Try to limit who you and your children interact with to the same people you typically are around.
Gather in large groups - this is a time to be close with those who are closest to you.
Visit each other’s homes or having sleepovers.
Share food or drink.
Avoid excessive media coverage of COVID-19.
Take care of their bodies. Take deep breaths, stretch or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, and get plenty of sleep.
Make time to unwind and try to do some other activities you enjoy.
Spend time outside - fresh air and exercise is one of the best things you can do over the next few weeks.
Share your concerns and how you are feeling with friends or family members. Maintain healthy relationships.
Use your technology and social media for good purposes - support one another and show that you care for one another.
Maintain a sense of hope and positive thinking.
Keep following the practice of washing your hands regularly and covering your cough or sneeze.

div.div: Information about COVID-19 is continually changing. I will communicate with you all immediately regarding any changes.
Respectfully,
Dear Argo Parents and Guardians,

Thank you for your support, patience and understanding during these unprecedented times dealing with COVID-19. Monitoring this situation includes frequent communications with all districts that feed into Argo Community High School, Districts 104, 108 and 109 and the Board of Education. After much discussion yesterday and today, we are recommending that our Districts be closed next week, March 16-30, 2020. All four Districts have spring break the following week, March 23-27. It is our hope that we will be back at school as usual on March 31. More information will be released later today about the details and expectations for next week.
All activities and athletics have been suspended until March 31, 2020.
Respectfully,
Dear Argo Community High School Families,

Thank you for your continued support and understanding for frequent communication regarding the Covid-19 (Coronavirus). At this time there are NO suspected or confirmed cases of Covid-19 (Coronavirus) at Argo Community High School. Classes and extracurricular events will proceed as usual until further notice.

We will continue to monitor the health advisories issued by the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), Centers for Disease Control (CDC), and the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) regarding Covid-19 (Coronavirus). Should the guidance or risk level change, we will be in communication with our families immediately.
Please reference the IDPH and CDC websites for all updates and guidance.

Again, we will continue to closely monitor recommendations regarding Covid-19 (Coronavirus) and will update you as soon as there are any significant changes in recommendations for schools. Thank you for your support in helping to keep our school community healthy.
Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield
Superintendent
Dear Argo Community High School Families,

The health and safety of our students and staff is our top priority. We continue to monitor the health advisories issued by the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), Centers for Disease Control (CDC), and the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) regarding Covid-19 (Coronavirus). As well, we are in frequent contact with our feeder school and conference school superintendents. Should the guidance or risk level change, we will be in communication with our families.

In the meantime, our custodial crews are taking extra care in cleaning high contact surfaces, desktops, doors, phones, door knobs, door handles, light switches, pencil sharpeners, water fountains, wellness rooms, weight rooms and more. There is hand sanitizer in most classrooms and wall mounted dispensers in the cafeteria. We use antimicrobial hand soap in the bathrooms and are being checked to make sure they are filled.

Students are being reminded often by teachers and staff about washing our hands often, avoiding touching our eyes/nose/mouth, covering our coughs/sneezes with a tissue or sleeve, and staying home when we're sick. These are the best preventative measures for everyone and especially to protect those with compromised immune systems and the elderly. Please remind your children of this often as well.

To see the complete recommendations to schools from IDPH, please go to http://www.dph.illinois.gov/. Again, we will continue to closely monitor recommendations regarding Covid-19 (Coronavirus) and will update you as soon as there are any significant changes in recommendations for schools. Thank you for your support in helping to keep our school community healthy.
Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield
Superintendent
Dear Argo Community High School Students, Staff and Families,

The health and safety of our students is our top priority, so we want to share with you information that the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has published for schools throughout the state.

The good news at this time is that the health risk to the general public from coronavirus remains low. Currently, the IDPH recommends schools hold classes and events as usual, and follow routine cleaning and disinfecting procedures; no special measures are necessary.
The IDPH also recommends the best way to protect against coronavirus is by taking the same everyday precautions against getting sick in general. These include:

ul.li: Washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoiding close contact with people who are sick.
Staying home when you are sick.
Covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched objects and surfaces.

div.div: To see the complete recommendations to schools from IDPH, please go to http://www.dph.illinois.gov/. We will continue to closely monitor recommendations regarding coronavirus and will update you as soon as there are any significant changes in recommendations for schools. Thank you for your support in helping to keep our school community healthy.
Sincerely,
Dr. Jill Kingsfield
Superintendent

font.b: We inspire, educate, and empower students to envision and achieve a positive future for themselves and their community.
